status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for your email regarding installing a bike lane along a bus stop on Massachusetts Avenue.  The Boston Transportation Department is working to find the right balance between all users of the road. Almost 15% of all traffic on Massachusetts Avenue is bicyclists during peak times and bike lanes makes it safer for them.  Conflicts, where buses have to pull to the curb at a stop across a bike lane is a situation that arises at for all bike lanes in Boston and other cities.  In these cases bicyclists are alerted about the conflict by providing dashed lines, signage and paint.

We partner with BPD to do proactive education, and have a robust program to help bicyclists travel safely, responsibly, and in accordance with the law.

status_notes: Case Noted. This was an emergency job by  National Grid. If you feel that you were inconvenienced please feel free to contact Peter Nagle, who is the Public Relations person for N Grid. His number is 617-293-1490.
description:
Last night my car was towed due to an emergency gas leak. I was three hours late to work trying to get my car back this morning, was told at the police station that I wouldn't have to pay for it because I was parked legally, but when I got to the tow lot, I was told I needed to pay $129. I called the police station and they said I did have to pay and need to go through the gas company for a refund. 

In total, this cost me three hours and $145 after transportation fees and an ATM fee because not only did nobody tell me I had to pay for it, Roberts Towing only takes cash. I don't understand why the police did not try to look up the registration by plate and call me to move my car. This would have saved me significant time, money and headache. If I'm lucky, I'll get the towing fee reimbursed but I'm out of luck for the rest of it. 

As a new resident to the city and state, I've experienced so many difficulties with basic processes that could so easily be improved.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for bringing your concern about perceived speeding to our attention. Please know that federal criteria in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) prevents cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control (Section 2B.04). Stop signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs. BTD is currently in the process of implementing the Neighborhood Slow Streets program for traffic calming in two pilot areas. We are developing an application process so that other neighborhoods can benefit from traffic calming and reduced speeds on their streets. You can learn more about the program at visionzeroboston.org/nss. We suggest that you also add any additional concerns to our ?safety issues? map at the following link: app01.cityofboston.gov/VZSafety/. status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) investigated and determined the following:. National Grid was repairing 25 feet of the gas main on Wabon St. They are required to post " No Parking Signs" 48 hours in advance of the work. National Grid usually posts the street in advance of the work, obviously in this case they did not. In addition I spoke to National Grid on why they worked past the permitted hours. In the first instance the supervisor sent the driver to the yard to get steel plates to secure the hole and the driver went to the wrong yard causing the crew to work late. Yesterday because of the heavy rain they needed to stay late to make sure the sidewalls of the hole was secure being back filling and paving. The work is now complete. The PWD told National Grid they must post ALL locations 48 hours in advance with no exceptions. They apologized and acknowledge that this should not have happened. That stated they do have a posting procedures in place and they have already spoken to the personnel involved to remind them of the mandatory requirement. The supervisor Terry Cleary will gladly take your call if you want to personally speak to a representative of National Grid. Note: Since there are 3 cases related this issue all of the responses will be the same. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951.

description:
Over a year ago, I requested speed humps on Virginia and Monadnock Streets. As I sit here, mopeds are flying up and down the one way roads - often in the wrong direction. This has been a daily occurrence all summer and into the fall. Since posting about this issue in May 2015, I have seen two efforts to solve the problem: 
1. On one afternoon, I saw a cop patrolling the intersection to ticket those who did not stop at the stop sign. Only ONCE in a year and a half have I seen someone enforcing the stop signs. As a stay-at-home mom, we are outside nearly every day, rain or snow or shine, so it is unlikely that  it has been patrolled more often and I just missed it.
2. A sign was hung that reads "Drive Slow" and has a picture of a running child. That's a nice gesture. However, the signs have been entirely ineffective considering the excessive speeding that still occurs at this intersection.

I ask you respectfully to please again consider my request for speed humps which will actually slow the traffic and lead to a safer road for my children and my neighbors' children. Please let me know the procedure on how to obtain these. Do I need a signed petition by neighbors? If so, I know this can happen.

Thank you.
Sincerely,
a concerned mother and neighbor

description: A tourist bus has been idling for nearly an hour outside, illegally double parked on Atlantic Ave. This is very unusual for our neighborhood. It's also loud and polluting our air. Please have a police officer have them tell to relocate.

Resident parking:

Due to the expanding neighborhood & the increase of cars & visitors (with out of state plates).   I am hopeful that the powers that be are working on a 7 days of week resident parking in all South Boston neighborhoods.  I moved to South Boston when I was 23 years old because I could afford it and I embraced the friendliness of this last neighborhood in the greater metro area.  23 years later I am still here and value what is left of this neighborhood & respect my community.  But, when I have to drive around for 20-30 minutes looking for a legal spot it infuriates me when I pass all the out of state plates taking up the much coveted parking spaces especially since I pay taxes here.
Please consider the 7 days a week rule;  most if not all the neighborhoods in Boston already enforce this.  
Your humble neighbor,
Kelley Bowker

description: Hello- I'm not sure the correct resource to reach out, but I live at 298 Commonwealth Ave and there has been an increasing issue with a homeless man sleeping in the entryway, such that no one can enter or exit the front door of the building. I want to be compassionate but I am a young woman who lives alone, and he won't leave when asked. The front door of the building doesn't have a lock (to the outdoors) but the door between the vestibule and indoors does, so he sleeps in between the doors. It used to be just once in awhile, but it has become almost every night the past few weeks. He arrives around midnight most nights and is there until about 7am, or as late as noon on weekends, and no one can come or leave the building. He also urinates all over the front steps every morning. Is there any way to receive some assistance in finding this man a better place to stay so we can get in and out of the building? Thanks so much in advance.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Department did not issue a street opening permit to Spectra for the pipeline work. The Federal Government issued the permit which allows Spectra to work Monday through Saturday 7am to 7pm. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) contacted Spectra and asked them why they were working beyond the Federally permitted hours .  They stated they had to do work on their substation on Grove St which is their private property.  They also stated that they tried to mitigate the noise through the use of sound blankets. They City informed Spectra going forward that if they were going to work on their private property they would notify the CIU 48 hours in advance. In addition, the City may have the noise levels measured to insure the decibel levels do not go above the City ordinance.  They agreed to those terms. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951.

description:
Hi. My family and I reside at 14 Guernsey Street in Roslindale. I am concerned about people driving recklessly through several nearby intersections:

1.  The Rotary at West Roxbury Police station/ Holy Name Parish. It is difficult to cross in the crosswalk(s) safely since drivers are often not willing/able to stop for pedestrians. Can the crosswalks be better marked or patrolled?

2.  The intersection of South Street at Guernsey Street, Roslindale. 
There are school bus stops along this section of SOUTH St.  Drivers use excessive speed when exiting Centre Street onto (the much narrower and pedestrian route) South Street. Drivers also routinely straddle the double yellow lines there. Please patrol and ticket, when possible. Thanks.

Thanks.
